intro: Cacalia ramiflora, commonly known as the branching bellflower, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the family Asteraceae, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is characterized by its showy, bell-shaped flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, open habitats such as meadows and stream banks. Its leaves are lance-shaped and often have a hairy texture, while its stems are slender and branching. Cacalia ramiflora blooms in late spring to early summer, producing clusters of pink or purple flowers that attract pollinators like bees and butterflies.
